title: Chinese Government provides CFA 8.5 billion grant to Ivorian Prime Minister's Office for unspecified purposes
description: According to the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the Chinese Government and the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Prime Minister's Office signed a CFA 8,572,024,097.33 grant agreement on November 4, 2014 for unspecified purposes. The AMP records a single grant disbursement worth CFA 8,551,127,623.52 on November 30, 2014. The project completion date is identified in the AMP as November 30, 2014.
staff_comments: 1. The system identification number for this project in the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) is 1120071337613. 2. It is possible that this grant was issued through a MOFCOM ETCA. This issue requires further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
UNALLOCATED/UNSPECIFIED

# Title
Chinese Government provides CFA 8.5 billion grant to Ivorian Prime Minister's Office for unspecified purposes

According to the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the Chinese Government and the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Prime Minister's Office signed a CFA 8,572,024,097.33 grant agreement on November 4, 2014 for unspecified purposes. The AMP records a single grant disbursement worth CFA 8,551,127,623.52 on November 30, 2014. The project completion date is identified in the AMP as November 30, 2014.
justification: Unspecified grant with no details about purpose or implementation
evidence: Grant agreement with no specified purpose or project details

title: China Eximbank provides $120 million loan for Port of Santiago Modernization Project
description: On July 22, 2014, China Eximbank and the Government of Cuba signed a $120 million loan agreement for the Port of Santiago Modernization Project.  The Port of Santiago is the second largest port in Cuba and is 900 kilometers east of the capital, Havana. Prior to project implementation, the port could only accommodate 20,000 ton ships, but its modernization with support from China Eximbank would reportedly allow 40,000 ton cargo ships to enter and exit.  The multipurpose port was meant have a length of 231.15 meters. The annual throughput of the terminal would reportedly be increased to 565,000 tons.  The project also included social infrastructure, a bifurcated railway branch for the transfer of loads, and state-of-the-art cargo equipment.  China Communications Construction Company was the contractor responsible for project implementation .  Construction began in January 2015 with the expansion of the multipurpose maritime terminal, Puerto Guillermón Moncada.  An on-site construction inspection was conducted on January 9, 2018 by Hong Xiao, the Economic and Commercial Counselor of the Chinese Embassy in Cuba, and his team.  Port construction activities were completed on June 9, 2018, and was opened in 2019.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 古巴圣地亚哥港多用途码头项目 or 古巴圣地亚哥海运港口项目.2. There are differing transaction amounts: An RFI source says that the construction of the port will require a $100 million loan from China, whereas a Factiva source says the loan is for RMB 730 million (which is roughly equivalent to $116 million). Xinhua, Granma, the Diplomat, and China MOFCOM source all say the loan was for $120 million.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Eximbank provides $120 million loan for Port of Santiago Modernization Project

# Description
On July 22, 2014, China Eximbank and the Government of Cuba signed a $120 million loan agreement for the Port of Santiago Modernization Project.  The Port of Santiago is the second largest port in Cuba and is 900 kilometers east of the capital, Havana. Prior to project implementation, the port could only accommodate 20,000 ton ships, but its modernization with support from China Eximbank would reportedly allow 40,000 ton cargo ships to enter and exit.  The multipurpose port was meant have a length of 231.15 meters. The annual throughput of the terminal would reportedly be increased to 565,000 tons.  The project also included social infrastructure, a bifurcated railway branch for the transfer of loads, and state-of-the-art cargo equipment.  China Communications Construction Company was the contractor responsible for project implementation .  Construction began in January 2015 with the expansion of the multipurpose maritime terminal, Puerto Guillermón Moncada.  An on-site construction inspection was conducted on January 9, 2018 by Hong Xiao, the Economic and Commercial Counselor of the Chinese Embassy in Cuba, and his team.  Port construction activities were completed on June 9, 2018, and was opened in 2019.
justification: Project focuses on port modernization and expansion without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Port modernization to accommodate larger ships, increased throughput capacity, railway branch, and cargo equipment

title: China Development Bank provides loan for acquisition of telecommunications equipment
description: In July 2014, China Development Bank and Banco Nacional de Cuba signed a loan agreement for the purchase of telecommunications equipment.  The face value and terms of the loan are unknown.
staff_comments: This loan likely supported telecommunication infrastructure construction activities of Empresa de Telecomunicaciones de Cuba S.A. (ETECSA), a government-owned telecommunications service provider for the Republic of Cuba

title: Chinese Government reschedules a 2003 interest-free loan to Cuba by postponing payment for 10 years (Linked to Project ID#88297)
description: On July 22, 2014, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cuba signed an exchange of letters in which the Chinese Government agreed to reschedule Cuba's payment on a 2003 interest-free loan loan by postponing the start of the loan's payment period by 10 years. The loan was originally provided, for unspecified purposes, under an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) signed on December 24, 2003 (captured via Project ID#88297). The monetary value and borrowing terms of the interest-free loan are unknown. The rescheduling agreement was signed by Gao Hucheng, Chinese Minister of Commerce, and Rodrigo Malmierca Díaz, Minister of Foreign Trade and Foreign Investment.
staff_comments: 1. As the original loan was made under an ETCA, which is a financing mechanism specific to China's Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM), AidData has coded MOFCOM as the specific Chinese Government institution responsible for providing this interest-free loan.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
Chinese Government reschedules a 2003 interest-free loan to Cuba by postponing payment for 10 years (Linked to Project ID#88297)

# Description
On July 22, 2014, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cuba signed an exchange of letters in which the Chinese Government agreed to reschedule Cuba's payment on a 2003 interest-free loan loan by postponing the start of the loan's payment period by 10 years. The loan was originally provided, for unspecified purposes, under an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) signed on December 24, 2003 (captured via Project ID#88297). The monetary value and borrowing terms of the interest-free loan are unknown. The rescheduling agreement was signed by Gao Hucheng, Chinese Minister of Commerce, and Rodrigo Malmierca Díaz, Minister of Foreign Trade and Foreign Investment.
justification: Loan rescheduling agreement with no specified environmental or energy-related purpose
evidence: Debt rescheduling of unspecified-purpose loan, financial transaction between governments

title: China Provides Water Measurement Equipment for Cuban Aqueduct Network
description: In 2014, China agreed to provide water measurement equipment to Cuba for an aqueduct network project in the provincial capitals.  The agreement was signed between Gao Hucheng, Minister of the Chinese Ministry of Commerce and Rodrigo Malmierca Díaz, Minister of the Cuban Ministry of Foreign Trade and Foreign Investment.  On 26 August, 2016, during the twenty-eighth session of the Intergovernmental Commission Cuba-China for economic and commercial relations, Rodrigo Malmierca, Cuban Minister of Foreign Trade and Foreign Investment, and Zhang Xiangchen, Vice President of International Trade Negotiations of the Chinese Ministry of Commerce, signed an act of delivery and reception of three projects successfully executed between both parties: the supply of water measurement equipment, Phase II of the Digital Television Deployment Project, and the supply of sanitation equipment for the capital.  The first of these three completed projects reflects the 2014 agreement described above.
combined_text:

WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION

# Title

# Description
In 2014, China agreed to provide water measurement equipment to Cuba for an aqueduct network project in the provincial capitals.  The agreement was signed between Gao Hucheng, Minister of the Chinese Ministry of Commerce and Rodrigo Malmierca Díaz, Minister of the Cuban Ministry of Foreign Trade and Foreign Investment.  On 26 August, 2016, during the twenty-eighth session of the Intergovernmental Commission Cuba-China for economic and commercial relations, Rodrigo Malmierca, Cuban Minister of Foreign Trade and Foreign Investment, and Zhang Xiangchen, Vice President of International Trade Negotiations of the Chinese Ministry of Commerce, signed an act of delivery and reception of three projects successfully executed between both parties: the supply of water measurement equipment, Phase II of the Digital Television Deployment Project, and the supply of sanitation equipment for the capital.  The first of these three completed projects reflects the 2014 agreement described above.
justification: Project focuses on water measurement equipment for aqueduct networks, which is unrelated to energy transition or environmental impact
evidence: Water measurement equipment for aqueduct network, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese Donation of Office and Transportation Equipment to Cuba
description: On July 22nd, 2014, China agreed to donate office and transportation equipment to Cuba—part of a series of agreements signed during Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to the island nation. The agreement, entitled in Spanish, "Canje de Notas entre el Gobierno de la República de Cuba y el Gobierno de la República Popular China," was signed by Gao Hucheng, Chinese Minister of the Ministry of Commerce and Rodrigo Malmierca Díaz, Cuban Minister of the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Foreign Investment. The status and the specific destination of the donation is unknown.

title: Chinese Donation of Environmental Monitoring Equipment to Cuba
description: On July 22nd, 2014, China agreed to donate environmental monitoring equipment to Cuba, as one of a lengthy series of accords signed during Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to the island nation. The agreement was signed by Elba Rosa Pérez Montoya of the Ministry of Science, Technology and Environment of Cuba and Zhang Tuo of the Ministry of Environmental Protection of China. Its stipulations were fulfilled on October 29th, 2015, when three fixed air quality monitoring stations were installed in Havana: one at the headquarters of the San Miguel del Padrón Municipal Administration Council; one at the Instituto Superior de Tecnologías y Ciencias Aplicadas; and one at the Cuban Meteorological Institute (INSMET), under the responsibility of one of its institutions, the Center for Atmospheric Contamination and Chemistry Studies (CECQA). Fernando Mario González Bermúdez, First Deputy Minister of the Ministry of Science, Technology and the Environment (CITMA); and Wu Xiaquing, China's Vice Minister of Environmental Protection, signed the delivery certificate.
staff_comments: This may be linked to a 2005 MOU according to Source ID #186161.
combined_text:

# Title
Chinese Donation of Environmental Monitoring Equipment to Cuba

# Description
On July 22nd, 2014, China agreed to donate environmental monitoring equipment to Cuba, as one of a lengthy series of accords signed during Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to the island nation. The agreement was signed by Elba Rosa Pérez Montoya of the Ministry of Science, Technology and Environment of Cuba and Zhang Tuo of the Ministry of Environmental Protection of China. Its stipulations were fulfilled on October 29th, 2015, when three fixed air quality monitoring stations were installed in Havana: one at the headquarters of the San Miguel del Padrón Municipal Administration Council; one at the Instituto Superior de Tecnologías y Ciencias Aplicadas; and one at the Cuban Meteorological Institute (INSMET), under the responsibility of one of its institutions, the Center for Atmospheric Contamination and Chemistry Studies (CECQA). Fernando Mario González Bermúdez, First Deputy Minister of the Ministry of Science, Technology and the Environment (CITMA); and Wu Xiaquing, China's Vice Minister of Environmental Protection, signed the delivery certificate.
justification: Project involves donation of environmental monitoring equipment without direct energy transition impact
evidence: Installation of air quality monitoring stations, environmental protection focus

title: CDB provides $60 million loan for Construction of 3 Biopesticide Production Plants and a Laboratory
description: In 2014, Hu Huaibang of China Development Bank and René Lazo Fernán­dez of the Cuban National Bank signed a financing agreement detailing a $60 million USD loan for the construction and purchase of equipment and supplies for three biopesticide production plants and a high-security laboratory in Cuba.  One of the three production facilities to be run by Labiofam for bio-pesticides and bio-fertilizers is on the outskirts of Villa Clara.  Construction started in 2014, and its expected completion was August 2016.  However, according to another source, as of 8 February 2019, the project was only 78.3% completed. The other two plants will be located in Granma and Havana. In October 2020, the second of the three plants was finished being built at Villa Clara. The setting up of equipment, however, will not be done until late 2021 due to Coronavirus restrictions.
staff_comments: There is some contention over the loan amount and currency: The Granma sources say that the Villa Clara plant will cost over $29 million dollars, and that China is financing the project, but they do not specifically say that the China Development Bank gave the National Bank of Cuba a $29 million loan. The Cuba Standard source says that during Xi Jingping's visit to Havana, China Development Bank chief Hu Huaibang signed an agreement that granted Cuba a loan, amount and conditions undisclosed, for the equipment and construction of three biopesticide plants. Another source claims the loan amount was 60,000,000 euros (See: Empresa Labiofam desarrolla plan de inversiones para fortalecer el sector agropecuario cubano). This project may have been funded by an export buyer's credit loan since the Cuban News Agency source says that the all of the equipment being used in the plant was imported from China using the facility (see 'Cuba keeps working..:'); however, AidData was unable to find record of this transaction in any official sources, so the flow type has been left as Loan (excluding debt rescheduling) for now.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
CDB provides $60 million loan for Construction of 3 Biopesticide Production Plants and a Laboratory

# Description
In 2014, Hu Huaibang of China Development Bank and René Lazo Fernán­dez of the Cuban National Bank signed a financing agreement detailing a $60 million USD loan for the construction and purchase of equipment and supplies for three biopesticide production plants and a high-security laboratory in Cuba.  One of the three production facilities to be run by Labiofam for bio-pesticides and bio-fertilizers is on the outskirts of Villa Clara.  Construction started in 2014, and its expected completion was August 2016.  However, according to another source, as of 8 February 2019, the project was only 78.3% completed. The other two plants will be located in Granma and Havana. In October 2020, the second of the three plants was finished being built at Villa Clara. The setting up of equipment, however, will not be done until late 2021 due to Coronavirus restrictions.
justification: Project focuses on agricultural infrastructure development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of biopesticide production plants and laboratory, agricultural sector focus

title: China funds Cuba Biotechnology Industry Base
description: In November 2014, a China-Cuba biotechnology industry base was set up in Wuhan National Bioindustry Base (also known as Biolake). The project has a total investment of 500 million yuan. After completion, it is expected to produce 60 million liquid preparations, 600 million tablets, 600 million capsules, and high-end APIs.500 kg annually. The exact Chinese investment amount is unknown. This project is supported by Hubei Province.
combined_text:

# Description
In November 2014, a China-Cuba biotechnology industry base was set up in Wuhan National Bioindustry Base (also known as Biolake). The project has a total investment of 500 million yuan. After completion, it is expected to produce 60 million liquid preparations, 600 million tablets, 600 million capsules, and high-end APIs.500 kg annually. The exact Chinese investment amount is unknown. This project is supported by Hubei Province.

title: China supports manufacturing plant for glucometers, biosensors, and other diagnostic equipment
description: On 22 July, 2014, China and Cuba jointly held the inauguration ceremony of a new manufacturing plant for biosensors, which measure the level of glucose in a diabetes patient’s blood, in Havana.  The plant, attached to the Cuban Immunoassay Center (CIE), will allow for the distribution of sensors to some 800,000 known diabetics in the country.  The modern facility’s creation came as a result of a government decision to make this type of equipment available to patients to support better management of the disease with regular measurement of glucose in the blood via a simple procedure, which the patient can perform personally.  The plant will be managed in cooperation with the SinoCare, which is a Chinese company owned by the global investment firm, KKR.  This plant is the result of a Memorandum of Understanding on cooperation in the field of biotechnology signed in 2004, although it is unclear what form Chinese financing took.
staff_comments: According to one source, this plant didn't materialize, but the Chinese Embassy website definitely specifies an inauguration ceremony (See: China-Cuba Relations: Assessing US Stakes).  This source also claims this project is a joint venture.
combined_text:
# Sector

# Description
On 22 July, 2014, China and Cuba jointly held the inauguration ceremony of a new manufacturing plant for biosensors, which measure the level of glucose in a diabetes patient’s blood, in Havana.  The plant, attached to the Cuban Immunoassay Center (CIE), will allow for the distribution of sensors to some 800,000 known diabetics in the country.  The modern facility’s creation came as a result of a government decision to make this type of equipment available to patients to support better management of the disease with regular measurement of glucose in the blood via a simple procedure, which the patient can perform personally.  The plant will be managed in cooperation with the SinoCare, which is a Chinese company owned by the global investment firm, KKR.  This plant is the result of a Memorandum of Understanding on cooperation in the field of biotechnology signed in 2004, although it is unclear what form Chinese financing took.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare equipment manufacturing without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Manufacturing plant for glucometers and biosensors, healthcare focus, no energy-related components mentioned
